controls.title: Ensure SELinux is installed
controls.rationale: Without a Mandatory Access Control system installed only the default Discretionary Access Control system will be available.
controls.audit:
Run the following command to verify libselinux is installed:
# rpm -q libselinux
libselinux-<version>
controls.remediation:
Run the following command to install SELinux:
# dnf install libselinux
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
v7: 14.6 Protect Information through Access Control Lists

controls.title: Ensure SELinux is not disabled in bootloader configuration
controls.description: Configure SELinux to be enabled at boot time and verify that it has not been overwritten by the grub boot parameters.
controls.rationale: SELinux must be enabled at boot time in your grub configuration to ensure that the controls it provides are not overridden.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify that no linux lines have the selinux=0 or enforcing=0 parameters set:
# grubby --info=ALL | grep -Po '(selinux|enforcing)=0'
Nothing should be returned
controls.remediation:
Edit /etc/default/grub and remove all instances of selinux=0 and enforcing=0 from all CMDLINE_LINUX parameters:
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT="quiet"
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX=""
Run the following command to update the grub2 configuration:
# grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
v7: 14.6 Protect Information through Access Control Lists

controls.title: Ensure SELinux policy is configured
controls.description: Configure SELinux to meet or exceed the default targeted policy, which constrains daemons and system software only.
controls.rationale: Security configuration requirements vary from site to site. Some sites may mandate a policy that is stricter than the default policy, which is perfectly acceptable. This item is intended to ensure that at least the default recommendations are met.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify output matches either targeted or mls:
# sestatus | grep 'Loaded policy name'
Loaded policy name:             targeted
OR
Loaded policy name:             mls
controls.remediation:
Edit the /etc/selinux/config file to set the SELINUXTYPE parameter:
SELINUXTYPE=targeted
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
v7: 14.6 Protect Information through Access Control Lists

controls.title: Ensure the SELinux mode is enforcing or permissive
controls.description: SELinux can run in one of three modes: disabled, permissive, or enforcing.
controls.rationale: Running SELinux in disabled mode is strongly discouraged; it is equivalent to not running SELinux at all. SELinux can provide valuable information when run in permissive mode, but provides no security benefit.
controls.audit:
Run the following command and verify output matches:
# getenforce
Enforcing
OR
Permissive
controls.remediation:
Edit the /etc/selinux/config file to set the SELINUX parameter:
SELINUX=enforcing
controls.cis_controls:
v8: 4.1 Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process
v7: 14.6 Protect Information through Access Control Lists

controls.title: Ensure access to /etc/issue is configured
controls.description:
\

\f2\b0 The contents of the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/issue
\f2 \cf2  file are displayed to users prior to login for local\
terminals.\

\f1\b
controls.rationale:
\
- IF -
\f2\b0  the 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/issue
\f2 \cf2  file does not have the correct access configured, it could be\
modified by unauthorized users with incorrect or misleading information.\

\f1\b
controls.audit_command:
\

\f2\b0 Run the following command and verify 
\f0 \cf4 Access
\f2 \cf2  is 
\f0 \cf4 644
\f2 \cf2  or more restrictive and 
\f0 \cf4 Uid
\f2 \cf2  and\

\f0 \cf4 Gid
\f2 \cf2  are both 
\f0 \cf4 0/root
\f2 \cf2 :\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 # stat -Lc 'Access: (%#a/%A) Uid: ( %u/ %U) Gid: \{ %g/ %G)' /etc/issue\
Access: (0644/-rw-r--r--) Uid: ( 0/ root) Gid: \{ 0/ root)\

\f1\b\fs24
controls.remediation:
\

\f2\b0 Run the following commands to set mode, owner, and group on 
\f0 \cf4 /etc/issue
\f2 \cf2 :\

\f4\fs20\fsmilli10080 # chown root:root $(readlink -e /etc/issue)\
# chmod u-x,go-wx $(readlink -e /etc/issue)\

\f1\b\fs24
controls.references:
\

\f2\b0 1. NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5: AC-3, MP-2
\fs20\fsmilli10080 Page 254\

\f0 Internal Only - General\

\f1\b\fs24
